ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Resonant peak splitting in graphene superlattices with one-dimensional periodic potentials

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Department of Physics, College of Sciences

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para:
We have investigated theoretically the resonant tunneling phenomenon of Dirac electrons through graphene superlattices with periodic potentials of square barriers. It is found that there are two resonance conditions for the graphene superlattices. Some of the resonance transmission peaks present N – 1-fold resonance splitting for
$$ N{\text{-barriers}} $$
N -barriers
, which is the analogy of the resonance splitting in semiconductor superlattices. The resonance splitting effect depends on the incidence angle rather than the height and width of the potential. However, there is no explicit splitting rule for the conductance and shot noise, which is different from the magnetic case. Furthermore, the resonant splitting rule of the transmission is not sensitive to the shape of the potential barrier. These properties in graphene superlattices may lead to potential applications in graphene-based electron devices.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para:
The transport properties of Schrödinger electrons (described by Schrödinger equation) in semiconductor superlattices have attracted much attention from both theoretical and experimental scientists since the concept of semiconductor superlattices was proposed by Tsu and Esaki [1] and realized by Chang et al. [2]. Tsu and Esaki [3] first demonstrated that the resonance transmission peak of Schrödinger electrons in
$$ n $$
n
barriers would split into
$$ (n - 1) $$
( n - 1 )
peaks based on their numerical calculation. This phenomenon was then analytically proved by Liu and Stamp [4, 5], and they demonstrated that the resonance splitting effect in semiconductor superlattices of periodic potentials structure with arbitrary profile in one dimensional is an inherent property of the semiconductor superlattices. Guo et al. [6] found that there is no explicit and general resonant peak splitting for transmission in magnetic superlattices, and the resonance splitting effect in magnetic barriers strongly depends on the tunneling momentum of electrons. Moreover, for ballistic conductance in magnetic superlattices with periodic arrangements of
$$ n $$
n
identical magnetic barriers in semiconductor, there exists a general
$$ (n - 1) $$
( n - 1 )
-fold resonant peak splitting rule [7], which is similar to the resonant splitting for transmission in electric superlattices in semiconductor.

Recently, the electron structure and transport properties of Dirac fermions in graphene [8–10] superlattices with electrostatic potential [11–21] and magnetic barriers [22–25] have been widely studied. The electrons in single-layer graphene are massless Dirac fermions, which are described by an effective massless Dirac equation at low energy, while the electrons in semiconductor are described by Schrödinger equation with parabolic energy dispersion. A novel electronic transport property in graphene is the perfect transmission in tunneling through an arbitrarily high and wide graphene barrier at normal incidence [26]. However, the transmission probability as a function of incidence energy has a gap when Dirac electrons transport through an electrostatic potential barrier in monolayer graphene at nonzero angle [27]. This transmission gap can be controlled by the incidence angle, the height and width of the potential barrier. The transmission gap also exists in graphene electric superlattices which can be modulated by the incidence angle, the number, height and width of the barriers [13]. Both semiconductor and graphene superlattices are vastly promising to control the electronic transport. Then, the question arises whether the resonance splitting effect also exists in Dirac electrons transport through graphene superlattices.

Actually, the resonance splitting effect through Kronig-Penney, step and sinusoidal magnetic superlattices in graphene have been investigated by Lu et al. [28, 29]. It is found that the transmission presents
$$ (n - 1){\text{-fold}} $$
( n - 1 ) -fold
resonance splitting for the magnetic superlattices with
$$ n{\text{-barriers}} $$
n -barriers
as well as the conductance and shot noise. This phenomenon is similar to the Schrödinger electrons in semiconductor superlattices. Recently, Sun et al. [30] found some line-type resonance peaks in a transmission gap when electrons transport through symmetric and asymmetric double barriers. The line-type resonance peaks are at unity for the symmetric double barriers structure, while strongly suppressed for the asymmetric case. Furthermore, when Dirac electrons transport through a quantum well consisting of graphene superlattices with modulated periodical potentials, the resonant modes have
$$ N{\text{-fold}} $$
N -fold
splitting with
$$ N $$
N
coupled quantum wells [31]. Motivated by these researches, we consider the Dirac electrons tunneling through a graphene superlattice with one-dimensional periodic electrostatic potentials. It is found that there is a splitting effect in electrons tunneling through the graphene superlattices. The resonance splitting is
$$ (N - 1){\text{-fold}} $$
( N - 1 ) -fold
with period number
$$ N $$
N
. This is due to the coupling between the wells via tunneling through the barriers, the degenerate eigenlevels of the independent wells become nondegenerate and split. Furthermore, the conductance and shot noise in the system are also studied in detail.

The paper is organized as follows: In Sect. 2, we introduce the method to calculate the transmission probability of Dirac electrons tunneling through single and periodic barriers. In Sect. 3, we analyze the resonance properties of the transmission probability for periodic potentials. The splitting effect for conductance and shot noise are shown in Sect. 4. Finally, we draw conclusions in Sect. 5.

The resonance splitting effect of Dirac electrons in graphene superlattices with periodic potentials is caused by the same physics in semiconductor superlattices [3] and the magnetic superlattices [28, 29] in graphene. Because of the coupling between the barriers and the well, there are several resonant peaks in the transmission gap for the double-barrier structure [30]. For the superlattices with
$$ N{\text{-barriers}} $$
N -barriers
, due to the coupling between the wells via tunneling through the barriers, the degenerate eigenlevels of the independent wells become nondegenerate and split, and the number of splittings is equal to that of the wells. Consequently, these splitting levels redistribute themselves into groups around their unperturbed position and form quasibands, which leads to the resonance splitting of transmission peaks in graphene superlattices with periodic potentials.

Section1.Para:
In summary, we have investigated the resonant tunneling phenomenon in Dirac electrons tunneling through graphene superlattices with periodic electrostatic potentials. The transmission probability has been calculated, and the resonance conditions are:

The resonance splitting effect for the transmission probability depends on the incidence angle, and the resonance peaks can be suppressed by adjusting the structure parameters. Moreover, the resonance splitting effect also exists in a sinusoidal periodic potential, which indicates that the resonant splitting rule of the transmission is not sensitive to the shape of the potential barrier. We hope these phenomena can be useful in designing graphene-based electron devices, such as a multichannel electron wave filter.
